title: 111_s623
content: The Act is titled the "Pre-existing Condition Patient Protection Act of 2009" and includes findings. The "Pre-existing Condition Patient Protection Act of 2009" includes findings on the high number of uninsured and underinsured individuals, the prevalence of chronic conditions, and the limitations imposed by insurance companies on coverage for pre-existing conditions. The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 does not protect individuals against pre-existing condition exclusions or waiting periods. When there is a 63-day gap in health insurance coverage, pre-existing condition exclusions can be imposed on them when they get a new policy. Eliminating pre-existing condition exclusions is crucial for ensuring all Americans have access to healthcare. A majority of Americans support the Federal Government requiring health insurance companies to cover anyone, even with prior illnesses. Elimination of pre-existing condition exclusions under group health plans is crucial for ensuring all Americans have access to healthcare. Elimination of pre-existing condition exclusions under group health plans is mandated by the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, ensuring no pre-existing condition exclusions can be imposed on participants or beneficiaries. The text chunk discusses changes to the affiliation period in health insurance coverage offered by a health maintenance organization. It includes amendments to definitions and subsections of the Act. The text chunk discusses the elimination of pre-existing condition exclusions in group health plans and health insurance coverage under the Public Health Service Act. It prohibits imposing pre-existing condition exclusions for participants or beneficiaries. The text chunk discusses changes to affiliation periods in health insurance coverage offered by health maintenance organizations under the Public Health Service Act. It eliminates the requirement for an affiliation period before coverage becomes effective and includes technical amendments related to employer size. The text chunk modifies affiliation periods in health insurance coverage under the Public Health Service Act by removing the requirement for an affiliation period and making technical amendments related to employer size. The text chunk modifies health insurance coverage under the Public Health Service Act by eliminating pre-existing condition exclusions and making technical changes to subsections. The text chunk modifies health insurance coverage under the Public Health Service Act by eliminating pre-existing condition exclusions and making technical changes to subsections, including striking certain paragraphs and redesignating subsections. The text chunk eliminates pre-existing condition exclusions for group health plans, with amendments applying after 12 months from the enactment of the Act, except for plans under collective bargaining agreements. The text chunk specifies that termination of collective bargaining agreements related to the plan will occur either without extension after the enactment of the Act or after the 12th calendar month following the Act. Amendments made to conform to new requirements will not be considered a termination of the agreement. SEC. 4. NONDISCRIMINATION IN INDIVIDUAL HEALTH INSURANCE. Section 2741 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to guarantee issue of health insurance coverage in the individual market, prohibiting denial of coverage or pre-existing condition exclusions for eligible individuals. The amendments made by this section ensure that health insurance coverage in the individual market cannot be denied or have pre-existing condition exclusions for eligible individuals. The effective date for these changes is after the 12th calendar month following the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. TRANSPARENCY IN CLAIMS DATA. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must submit a report to Congress on adverse selection within 2 years of this Act. Health insurance issuers must provide data upon request, including new enrollees, re-enrollees, demographic characteristics, and claims information. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must report on enrollees, disenrollment, and other relevant information. Enforcement measures are added to the Public Health Service Act. "SEC. 2793. PROVISION OF INFORMATION." The Secretary requires group health plans and insurance issuers to provide data for monitoring compliance with the Act. Failure to provide information may result in civil penalties of up to $100 per covered life per day. The Secretary may impose civil penalties for non-compliance with the Act, taking into account previous compliance and the severity of the violation. The Government Accountability Office must submit a report to the Secretary of Health and Human Services within 12 months of the Act's enactment. The report will assess the impact of the Act and other federal laws on health insurance regulation, focusing on affordability for individuals in all insurance markets. It will also analyze the Act's influence on expanding coverage and reducing the number of uninsured and underinsured individuals.
